content: The much quoted Warren Buffet on Obamas extra stuff on the Econo bill. Remember us dumb conservatives that are just haters because we see the agenda and using the economy as an excuse to get this agenda passed. I guess Warren Buffett is a hater and dumbazz too. quote: BUFFETT: …And, Joe, it–if you’re in a war, and we really are on an economic war, there’s a obligation to the majority to behave in ways that don’t go around inflaming the minority. If on December 8th when–maybe it’s December 7th, when Roosevelt convened Congress to have a vote on the war, he didn’t say, `I’m throwing in about 10 of my pet projects … [snip] … JOE: Yeah, but you might–might not have fixed… BUFFETT: But I say… JOE: You might not–you might not have fixed global warming the day after–the day after D-Day, Warren. BUFFETT: Absolutely. And I think that the–I think that the Republicans have an obligation to regard this as an economic war and to realize you need one leader and, in general, support of that. But I think that the–I think that the Democrats–and I voted for Obama and I strongly support him, and I think he’s the right guy–but I think they should not use this–when they’re calling for unity on a question this important, they should not use it to roll the Republicans all. JOE: Hm. BUFFETT: I think–I think a lot of things should be–job one is to win the war, job–the economic war, job two is to win the economic war, and job three. And you can’t expect people to unite behind you if you’re trying to jam a whole bunch of things down their throat. So I would–I would absolutely say for the–for the interim, till we get this one solved, I would not be pushing a lot of things that are–you know are contentious, and I also–I also would do no finger-pointing whatsoever. I would–you know, I would not say, you know, `George’–`the previous administration got us into this.’ Forget it. I mean, you know, the Navy made a mistake at Pearl Harbor and had too many ships there. But the idea that we’d spend our time after that, you know, pointing fingers at the Navy, we needed the Navy. So I would–I would–I would–no finger-pointing, no vengeance, none of that stuff. Just look forward. ..[snip] … BUFFETT: Well, I was going to mention to Joe that you’ve heard this comment recently from some Democrats recently that a `crisis is a terrible thing to waste.’ BECKY: Yeah. BUFFETT: Now, just rephrase that and since it’s, in my view, it’s an economic war, and–I don’t think anybody on December 7th would have said a `war is a terrible thing to waste, and therefore we’re going to try and ram through a whole bunch of things and–but we expect to–expect the other party to unite behind us on the–on the big problem.’ It’s just a mistake, I think, when you’ve got one overriding objective, to try and muddle it up with a bunch of other things. <edit> He's against "card check." ("I think the secret ballot's pretty important in the country.") 'http://www.slate.com/blogs/blogs/kausfiles/archive/2009/03/09/obama-buffetted.aspx'
quote: BUFFETT: …And, Joe, it–if you’re in a war, and we really are on an economic war, there’s a obligation to the majority to behave in ways that don’t go around inflaming the minority. If on December 8th when–maybe it’s December 7th, when Roosevelt convened Congress to have a vote on the war, he didn’t say, `I’m throwing in about 10 of my pet projects … [snip] … JOE: Yeah, but you might–might not have fixed… BUFFETT: But I say… JOE: You might not–you might not have fixed global warming the day after–the day after D-Day, Warren. BUFFETT: Absolutely. And I think that the–I think that the Republicans have an obligation to regard this as an economic war and to realize you need one leader and, in general, support of that. But I think that the–I think that the Democrats–and I voted for Obama and I strongly support him, and I think he’s the right guy–but I think they should not use this–when they’re calling for unity on a question this important, they should not use it to roll the Republicans all. JOE: Hm. BUFFETT: I think–I think a lot of things should be–job one is to win the war, job–the economic war, job two is to win the economic war, and job three. And you can’t expect people to unite behind you if you’re trying to jam a whole bunch of things down their throat. So I would–I would absolutely say for the–for the interim, till we get this one solved, I would not be pushing a lot of things that are–you know are contentious, and I also–I also would do no finger-pointing whatsoever. I would–you know, I would not say, you know, `George’–`the previous administration got us into this.’ Forget it. I mean, you know, the Navy made a mistake at Pearl Harbor and had too many ships there. But the idea that we’d spend our time after that, you know, pointing fingers at the Navy, we needed the Navy. So I would–I would–I would–no finger-pointing, no vengeance, none of that stuff. Just look forward. ..[snip] … BUFFETT: Well, I was going to mention to Joe that you’ve heard this comment recently from some Democrats recently that a `crisis is a terrible thing to waste.’ BECKY: Yeah. BUFFETT: Now, just rephrase that and since it’s, in my view, it’s an economic war, and–I don’t think anybody on December 7th would have said a `war is a terrible thing to waste, and therefore we’re going to try and ram through a whole bunch of things and–but we expect to–expect the other party to unite behind us on the–on the big problem.’ It’s just a mistake, I think, when you’ve got one overriding objective, to try and muddle it up with a bunch of other things. <edit> He's against "card check." ("I think the secret ballot's pretty important in the country.") 'http://www.slate.com/blogs/blogs/kausfiles/archive/2009/03/09/obama-buffetted.aspx'
reply: The much quoted Warren Buffet on Obamas extra stuff on the Econo bill. Remember us dumb conservatives that are just haters because we see the agenda and using the economy as an excuse to get this agenda passed. I guess Warren Buffett is a hater and dumbazz too.
title: Obama Buffetted

content: he's not a "hater and a dumbazz". he's talking about stragaty to win the "economic war". about building up support. not about pork or extra spending.
reply: he's not a "hater and a dumbazz". he's talking about stragaty to win the "economic war". about building up support. not about pork or extra spending.
title: Obama Buffetted

content: quote: So I would–I would absolutely say for the–for the interim, till we get this one solved, I would not be pushing a lot of things that are–you know are contentious Buffett is a smart one, but of this, he knows little. The president is merely taking advantage of his political capital. Pretty smart move.
quote: So I would–I would absolutely say for the–for the interim, till we get this one solved, I would not be pushing a lot of things that are–you know are contentious
reply: Buffett is a smart one, but of this, he knows little. The president is merely taking advantage of his political capital. Pretty smart move.
title: Obama Buffetted

content: quote: Originally posted by FrJohn1123: quote: So I would–I would absolutely say for the–for the interim, till we get this one solved, I would not be pushing a lot of things that are–you know are contentious Buffett is a smart one, but of this, he knows little. The president is merely taking advantage of his political capital. Pretty smart move. Buffett is a financier, and a damned good one, at that. However, he's losing money just like the rest of us and wants the problem fixed without too many distractions.

content: The economy needs to be rid of mark to market and needs uptick restored, and you'd see confidence restored in SOME and another tripple didget rebound. An executive order could resolve that. Yet, his Admin. won't mention it at all. Why is that? Mr. Obama is too used to campaigning and not performing his job. He is running for re-election even today rather than take positive action on the economy, and the Taliban hav e responded to his offer to negotiate have rejected the thought completely today. NOW what's the plan for victory?
reply: The economy needs to be rid of mark to market and needs uptick restored, and you'd see confidence restored in SOME and another tripple didget rebound. An executive order could resolve that. Yet, his Admin. won't mention it at all. Why is that? Mr. Obama is too used to campaigning and not performing his job. He is running for re-election even today rather than take positive action on the economy, and the Taliban hav e responded to his offer to negotiate have rejected the thought completely today. content: quote: Originally posted by peter3_1: The economy needs to be rid of mark to market and needs uptick restored, and you'd see confidence restored in SOME and another tripple didget rebound. An executive order could resolve that. Yet, his Admin. won't mention it at all. Why is that? Mr. Obama is too used to campaigning and not performing his job. He is running for re-election even today rather than take positive action on the economy, and the Taliban hav e responded to his offer to negotiate have rejected the thought completely today. NOW what's the plan for victory? He can't get rid of the "mark-to-market" accounting standard. The Emergency Economic Stabilization Act of 2008 requires the Securities and Exchange Commission to study the accounting method and report back to Congress the results. Go find something else to whine about.

Remember us dumb conservatives that are just haters because we see the agenda and using the economy as an excuse to get this agenda passed. I guess Warren Buffett is a hater and dumbazz too. quote: BUFFETT: …And, Joe, it–if you’re in a war, and we really are on an economic war, there’s a obligation to the majority to behave in ways that don’t go around inflaming the minority. If on December 8th when–maybe it’s December 7th, when Roosevelt convened Congress to have a vote on the war, he didn’t say, `I’m throwing in about 10 of my pet projects … [snip] … JOE: Yeah, but you might–might not have fixed… BUFFETT: But I say… JOE: You might not–you might not have fixed global warming the day after–the day after D-Day, Warren. BUFFETT: Absolutely. And I think that the–I think that the Republicans have an obligation to regard this as an economic war and to realize you need one leader and, in general, support of that. But I think that the–I think that the Democrats–and I voted for Obama and I strongly support him, and I think he’s the right guy–but I think they should not use this–when they’re calling for unity on a question this important, they should not use it to roll the Republicans all. JOE: Hm. BUFFETT: I think–I think a lot of things should be–job one is to win the war, job–the economic war, job two is to win the economic war, and job three. And you can’t expect people to unite behind you if you’re trying to jam a whole bunch of things down their throat. So I would–I would absolutely say for the–for the interim, till we get this one solved, I would not be pushing a lot of things that are–you know are contentious, and I also–I also would do no finger-pointing whatsoever. I would–you know, I would not say, you know, `George’–`the previous administration got us into this.’ Forget it. I mean, you know, the Navy made a mistake at Pearl Harbor and had too many ships there. But the idea that we’d spend our time after that, you know, pointing fingers at the Navy, we needed the Navy. BUFFETT: Now, just rephrase that and since it’s, in my view, it’s an economic war, and–I don’t think anybody on December 7th would have said a `war is a terrible thing to waste, and therefore we’re going to try and ram through a whole bunch of things and–but we expect to–expect the other party to unite behind us on the–on the big problem.’ It’s just a mistake, I think, when you’ve got one overriding objective, to try and muddle it up with a bunch of other things. <edit> He's against "card check." ("I think the secret ballot's pretty important in the country.") 'http://www.slate.com/blogs/blogs/kausfiles/archive/2009/03/09/obama-buffetted.aspx' So GunnyRet03 you are agreeing with Buffet that Obama is "the right guy" for this situation and Republicans should support him "realize you need one leader and, in general, support of that". Heck I think even Obama would have preferred a more straight forward stimlus bill and less in the pork in the left over Bush 2009 budget (which the Repubs did NOT fight in committee). quote: BUFFETT: Absolutely. And I think that the–I think that the Republicans have an obligation to regard this as an economic war and to realize you need one leader and, in general, support of that. But I think that the–I think that the Democrats–and I voted for Obama and I strongly support him, and I think he’s the right guy–but I think they should not use this–when they’re calling for unity on a question this important, they should not use it to roll the Republicans all.

I guess Warren Buffett is a hater and dumbazz too. quote: BUFFETT: …And, Joe, it–if you’re in a war, and we really are on an economic war, there’s a obligation to the majority to behave in ways that don’t go around inflaming the minority. If on December 8th when–maybe it’s December 7th, when Roosevelt convened Congress to have a vote on the war, he didn’t say, `I’m throwing in about 10 of my pet projects … [snip] … JOE: Yeah, but you might–might not have fixed… BUFFETT: But I say… JOE: You might not–you might not have fixed global warming the day after–the day after D-Day, Warren. BUFFETT: Absolutely. And I think that the–I think that the Republicans have an obligation to regard this as an economic war and to realize you need one leader and, in general, support of that. But I think that the–I think that the Democrats–and I voted for Obama and I strongly support him, and I think he’s the right guy–but I think they should not use this–when they’re calling for unity on a question this important, they should not use it to roll the Republicans all. JOE: Hm. BUFFETT: I think–I think a lot of things should be–job one is to win the war, job–the economic war, job two is to win the economic war, and job three. And you can’t expect people to unite behind you if you’re trying to jam a whole bunch of things down their throat. So I would–I would absolutely say for the–for the interim, till we get this one solved, I would not be pushing a lot of things that are–you know are contentious, and I also–I also would do no finger-pointing whatsoever. I would–you know, I would not say, you know, `George’–`the previous administration got us into this.’ Forget it. I mean, you know, the Navy made a mistake at Pearl Harbor and had too many ships there. But the idea that we’d spend our time after that, you know, pointing fingers at the Navy, we needed the Navy. So I would–I would–I would–no finger-pointing, no vengeance, none of that stuff. Just look forward. ..[snip] … BUFFETT: Well, I was going to mention to Joe that you’ve heard this comment recently from some Democrats recently that a `crisis is a terrible thing to waste.’ BECKY: Yeah. BUFFETT: Now, just rephrase that and since it’s, in my view, it’s an economic war, and–I don’t think anybody on December 7th would have said a `war is a terrible thing to waste, and therefore we’re going to try and ram through a whole bunch of things and–but we expect to–expect the other party to unite behind us on the–on the big problem.’ It’s just a mistake, I think, when you’ve got one overriding objective, to try and muddle it up with a bunch of other things. <edit> He's against "card check." ("I think the secret ballot's pretty important in the country.") 'http://www.slate.com/blogs/blogs/kausfiles/archive/2009/03/09/obama-buffetted.aspx' So GunnyRet03 you are agreeing with Buffet that Obama is "the right guy" for this situation and Republicans should support him "realize you need one leader and, in general, support of that". Heck I think even Obama would have preferred a more straight forward stimlus bill and less in the pork in the left over Bush 2009 budget (which the Repubs did NOT fight in committee). Why did the dems not fight it? They had the majority the last 2 yrs? Dems own it. Besides Repub and conserv people have been against it all along, that didnt change and doesnt now, and with that Dems still luvs them sum pork, nothings changed quote: BUFFETT: Absolutely. And I think that the–I think that the Republicans have an obligation to regard this as an economic war and to realize you need one leader and, in general, support of that. But I think that the–I think that the Democrats–and I voted for Obama and I strongly support him, and I think he’s the right guy–but I think they should not use this–when they’re calling for unity on a question this important, they should not use it to roll the Republicans all.
reply: No, I am not agreeing with him on he is the One, he is a supporter and when a supporter see's a problem maybe someone should listen. Since you like to quote Buffett all the time, I left that part of the quotes in the post co'z I knew y'all would latch on to that to try to counter what Buffett said about the agenda shotgun approach to the economy and using it against someone that opposes obama on this policy. I will bet that if Obama keeps going on this track Buffett will reconsider he support. BUFFETT: Now, just rephrase that and since it’s, in my view, it’s an economic war, and–I don’t think anybody on December 7th would have said a `war is a terrible thing to waste, and therefore we’re going to try and ram through a whole bunch of things and–but we expect to–expect the other party to unite behind us on the–on the big problem.’ It’s just a mistake, I think, when you’ve got one overriding objective, to try and muddle it up with a bunch of other things. More stimuli on the way....
title: Obama Buffetted
